GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Markham Gas Processing Plant is a facility that is covered by Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations (OSHA 1910). The essential provision of PSM is Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - a careful review of what could go wrong and what safeguards must be implemented to prevent releases of hazardous chemicals. Through a series of PHAs, the entire process at the Markham Plant has been reviewed, and the plant is in the process of revalidating the existing PHAs.
The PSM program of the plant requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire process. The approach addresses the process design, process technology, process changes operational and maintenance activities and procedures, non-routine activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans

and procedures, training program, and other elements that affect the process. All procedures are considered in the evaluation. To assist the location in the implementation of the PSM program, the plant has assigned a person to the sole responsibility of PSM coordinator, and this person is responsible directly to management.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION
The Markham Gas Processing Plant maintains a written emergency response program to protect the personnel and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire and/or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs. Employees receive monthly training in these procedures to perform emergency response duties. The program is updated annually due to possible modifications made to the gas plant. These changes are administered through Management of Change (MOC) process and our Tulsa office. The overall emergency response program for the Markham Gas Processing Plant is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination included attending periodic meetings of the committee that included local emergency response officials and industry representatives. The facility has 24-hour communications capability with Matagorda County's LEPC, along with offering the local fire department and other emergency response organizations the opportunity to participate in periodic MOCK emergency drills. Markham Gas Processing Plant EOP manual is also updated annually and delivered to our emergency response officials and various industry representatives.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
We have not had a single release of a regulated substance at the Markham Gas Proc

essing Plant facility within the last five years. This accomplishment is attributed to the stringent release prevention policy mandated by the Williams management group and executed by each employee.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Markham Gas Processing Plant will have an initial employee training, which includes 24 hours of HAZWOPER and 16 hours OSHA training. This initial training includes principals of incident command and emergency response, as well as fire fighting techniques.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES
The employees at the Markham Gas Processing Plant are strongly committed to EMPLOYEE, PUBLIC and ENVIRONMENTAL SAFETY. The commitment is demonstrated by conforming to our Process Safety Management Program and various resources invested in accident prevention. MOCK emergency drills are conducted monthly and specific training of our personnel is required in order to eliminate the occurrence of possible hazards. These goals are achieved with every project design, installation, operation and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement the appropriate controls to prevent any possible release of our regulated substances to the surrounding public domains, existing waterways and/or animal habitats. The Emergency Response Plan (ERP) utilized at the Markham Gas Processing Plant includes designated procedures mandated by the Williams management group. These specific procedures are for notification of agencies, evacuation of public receptors and response of trained personnel to control and contain the release.

THE STATIONY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Markham Gas Processing Plant is located in a rural area of Matagorda County, Texas I&GN AA Co. Survey A-329. The physical located is 1 1/2 miles northeast of Markham, Texas on Farm Maintenance Road FM2175. We have regulated substances present at our facility; they include all of which are extracted from the inlet natural gas stream. Listed below are the maximum inventory quantities.

Methane      44,000 lbs        Butanes      19,000 lbs
Ethane        37,000 lbs         Pentanes    16,000 lbs
Propane      26,000 lbs
